The satyagraha movement consisted of non-violent acts of disobedience, such as disobedience in the face of unjust laws, or protest marches in the face of apartheid laws. His method was based on the idea of active non-violent resistance to authority and oppression, or satyagraha, and was intended to be a non-violent form of protest against colonialism. It has been described by Gandhi as a "method of non-cooperation" which is a strategy of "satyagraha" or non-cooperation which has been adopted by Mahatma Gandhi, who was deeply influenced by the Indian Independence Movement. The Satyagraha Movement of Mahatma Gandhi has had several impacts in modern India. Gandhi, who was known as "father of the nation" was a key figure in India's independence movement. In a way that is often called Satyagraha movement, Gandhi sought to change the colonial administration of India by the exercise of non-violent resistance. The method was initially used in the Indian Independence Movement, later adopted by Gandhi in several other movements in the 20th century.

Alexander the Great.passage: "Alexander the Great was a Macedonian king, considered by many to be one of the most influential individuals in world history. He was a powerful military commander, using his charisma, skill, and tactical genius to create one of the most dominant empires of its time. During his reign, Alexander controlled most of the known world from Greece to India and from the Atlantic Ocean to Central Asia. He was considered to be the greatest military strategist in history by many military experts and historians. His success allowed him to unite a number of different cultures and religions that had previously been in conflict. His empire spread to much of the world, and his conquests helped shape its modern borders. He is credited with unifying the Greek world and initiating a trend of Hellenistic rule, which continued in various forms until the Roman Empire's fall in 476 CE. In his later years, he focused more on administration and politics. The most famous of his accomplishments was the creation of the city of Alexandria, Egypt, by order of Ptolemy II. The city served as an important centre for scientific knowledge and intellectual pursuits. After his death in 323 BCE, he was buried at his native Macedonia. Alexander's life and his influence over two empires was the subject of a controversial biographical novel by George S. Clore, Alexander the Great. In 1974, the BBC produced a television series which followed his life.

James Madison.passage: "." Now I am not arguing the proposition in general, but it seems to me there is a lot of confusion in the world about James Madison and the US Constitution. When I was in high school in the 80's I was told there were only two parties in the US, the Democratic Party and the Republican Party, and only two political positions, liberals and conservatives, or more simply as Democrats and Republicans. I have a very hard time with the argument about it being a "two-party system." There are not only two parties in the US, not only two positions, but there are other parties, such as the Green Party, the Libertarian Party, the Constitution Party, and various other third-party and independent candidates. So it seems a bit strange to me that there would be any confusion over that. So how is it that James Madison is viewed as a "Federalist"? How is it that his Federalist papers are regarded as "important works"? I am still not sure. It seems to me that if the government is only supposed to provide the Constitution and is supposed to be limited to only three branches, and is supposed to be limited to the separation of powers, how does a Federalist become Federalist and vice versa? There are so many questions, but I am still trying to figure out what the heck I am missing.

He was a key figure in the Constitutional Convention of 1787, which wrote the US Constitution. the African National Congress.passage: “The South African National Congress (SANC), African National Congress (ANC) or African National Congress-South African Communist Party (ANC-SACP) was the governing party of the African National Congress during apartheid in South Africa. The SANSISI (Swa-Afrikaans National and International Students' Organisation) was a youth arm of the ANC. “SISA also was a branch of the ANC in Zambia. The SANSISI were established in 1984 to unite students from different countries in Southern Africa in an organisation that could challenge apartheid in South Africa. This structure was developed to counter the white settler power structure in South Africa where they were the only ones who were white and where everything was built on them. In 1994, the SANSISI (South Africa International Students) was established in Swaziland to unite African students who were studying abroad to combat apartheid in South Africa. SANSISI was eventually banned. The SANC was founded in 1912, by the majority of Africans, in Cape Town, the second largest city in South Africa, in protest against the pass system. When the pass system was abolished, the SANSISI was renamed in 1990 as SANSISI and changed to the African National Congress-South African Communist Party (ANC-SACP).

Baktai Khan.passage: Baktai Khan (Old Tibetan: dGa'ung kha) was a Tibetan ruler during the rule of Emperor Songtsan Gampo, who ruled over an area of modern-day Xizang, Yunnan and Sichuan. This reign is considered the most important of Tibetan rulers, especially due to its duration from 1304 until 1354, and the introduction of a new type of script called Yulhun script. Balha.passage: "After Balha's victory over the Huns in the battle of Balha, the Huns invaded the Byzantine Empire in 6 AD and established a ruling settlement at the capital city of Constantinople. However, by 550 AD they had become part of the Byzantine Empire again, where the Huns continued their raids, with occasional attempts to invade the eastern Roman Empire. However, during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Maurice, their leader Balha was captured. He was sent to Constantinople, where he was tortured to death. Some Huns were put to death by the Byzantines, and others were exiled to the Greek island of Crete. The Huns withdrew from the Byzantine territories for several years. But a new group of Huns that was captured in 551 AD, became more powerful and by the year 565 AD established their capital at Dijla, where the Byzantines had lost their control of the town in 476 AD. The Huns later turned their sight against the Byzantine Empire, which they attacked several times between 565 AD and 586 AD. These Huns were more warlike than the previous ones and they forced the Byzantines to retreat in 550 AD, when they were able to settle in Crete for two years. This caused the Byzantines to launch a new wave of raids on the Huns in 556 AD.

Central Asia.passage: "The term Central Asia generally refers to the area in and around the Caspian Sea which includes Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan. The term was first used by French and Russian cartographers to describe a geographical area containing the countries that lie between the Caspian Sea, Siberia, and the China-bound Ural Mountains. In modern usage, the term is often applied more narrowly to the four countries of Central Asia, although it is not always clear to which four countries these actually apply. Generally the four countries are Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Turkmenistan (Turkmenistan is sometimes included as part of the Central Asian states and is therefore included in the four). In the context of the Soviet Union, it generally also included the four countries of the U.S.S.R. which became part of the Russian Federation after the breakup of the Soviet Union, and sometimes with Afghanistan and Iran as well.

Macedonia.passage: "Macedonia (Gr. Μακεδονη, modern Macedon, in 1913 'Махангарскга' [Μαχανγάρκη] in the Ancient Greek language, meaning "the country of the ancestors") is a country located in the southeastern part of Europe, which has been the focus of much recent Balkan ethnic and political controversy. The main city is Skopje, which was declared capital in 1991. Macedonia, a unitary multiethnic state in the Republic of Macedonia, is bordered on the north by Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Albania, and Greece, on the west by Greece and the Balkan Peninsula, on the south by Turkey and Bulgaria, on the east by Bulgaria and Serbia. The state's northern boundary runs through the mountain system of the Balkan peninsula, separating Macedonia from Albania and Serbia. The majority of the population (approximately 63%) belong to the Bulgarian ethnic group; the second-largest group (about 15%) are ethnic Albanians. Albanian and Bulgarian are the main languages, but in the capital city, the Slavic languages of Serbo-Croatian, Croatian and Slovenian are widely used.

the Atlantic Ocean.passage: The Atlantic Ocean is the world's largest ocean and the only one among the five oceans without any natural land borders.
